Ex Quanta Inc (d.b.a Zenlytic)
## Conflict of Interest/Code of Ethics Policy
Version: 0.0
Policy Owner: Paul Blankley
Status: Implemented
## Overview
At Zenlytic, we strive to maintain the highest levels of ethical conduct and integrity in our operations. The aim of our Conflict of Interest/Code of Ethics policy is to ensure that all personnel avoid situations where personal interests could conflict, or appear to conflict, with the interests of the company or our customers. This document details our commitment to this policy in accordance with SOC2 Trust Services Criteria.
## Objective
The objective of this document is to establish and communicate the Conflict of Interest/Code of Ethics policy for our organization and provide guidance to all employees and other stakeholders regarding their responsibilities to uphold this policy.
## Scope
This policy applies to all Zenlytic employees, contractors, consultants, board members, and other workers, including all personnel affiliated with third parties.
## Policy
- Conflict of Interest: All employees must avoid situations where their personal or financial interests could potentially conflict with their obligations to the company or its customers. Any potential conflict of interest must be disclosed to management immediately.
- Gifts and Hospitality: Employees should not offer or accept gifts or hospitality that could be viewed as an attempt to influence business decisions. Any gifts offered or received above a nominal value should be reported to management.
- Transparency and Integrity: All business dealings should be conducted transparently, honestly, and with the highest levels of integrity. Any fraudulent or dishonest activities are strictly prohibited.
- Confidentiality: Employees are required to maintain the confidentiality of company and customer information at all times and must not use such information for personal gain.
- Training: 
- Compliance: Compliance with this policy is mandatory for all employees and non-compliance will be treated as a serious matter, potentially leading to disciplinary action.
## Violation of the Policy
Violations of this policy will not be tolerated and may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment or contract, legal action, and criminal charges, as applicable.
## Policy Enforcement
The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) is responsible for enforcing this policy. All managers and team leaders are also responsible for ensuring their team members are aware of and comply with this policy.
## Revision History
This policy will be reviewed and updated at least annually or whenever significant changes occur to ensure its continued relevance and effectiveness.

Ex Quanta Inc (d.b.a Zenlytic)
## Clear Desk & Screen Policy
Version: 0.0
Policy Owner: Paul Blankley
Status: Implemented
## Overview
Our commitment to the SOC2 Trust Services Criteria reflects the dedication we have towards our customers' information security. Confidentiality of Customer Matters is a key aspect of this commitment. This document defines how our organization is meeting and upholding this criterion by implementing suitable measures and controls.
## Objective
The objective of this document is to establish the Confidentiality of Customer Matters policy for our organization and provide guidance to all employees and other stakeholders regarding their responsibilities to maintain and enforce this policy.
## Scope
This policy applies to all employees, contractors, consultants, and other workers at Zenlytic, including all personnel affiliated with third parties.
## Policy
- Confidential Information: All customer data collected, stored, processed, and transmitted by our business intelligence tool are to be considered confidential. This includes, but is not limited to, business insights, operational data, transactional data, user data, and any other information proprietary to the customer.
- Access Control: Access to confidential customer information shall be strictly regulated and granted only on a "need-to-know" basis. User access rights are reviewed periodically to ensure they are consistent with job responsibilities and our business needs.
- Security Measures: Appropriate technical and physical safeguards shall be implemented to protect confidential customer information. This includes encryption, intrusion detection and prevention systems, firewalls, secure disposal of data, and secure storage areas for physical data.
- Confidentiality Agreements: All employees, contractors, and third parties are required to sign confidentiality agreements as part of their employment or contractual engagement. The agreement specifies that they must protect and use confidential information appropriately.
- Training: All employees must participate in regular training to understand data confidentiality principles, requirements, and penalties for violating the policy. Training is updated annually or as necessary to reflect changes in the policy, technology, and business operations.
- Incident Reporting: Any suspected or actual breach of this policy must be reported immediately to the Information Security team. The team will investigate and respond to the incident as per the CC2.3.3 Incident Management policy.
- Review: This policy shall be reviewed at least annually or when significant changes occur to ensure its continued relevance and effectiveness.
## Violation of the Policy
Violations of this policy will not be tolerated and may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment or contract, legal action, and criminal charges, as applicable.
## Policy Enforcement
The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) is responsible for enforcing this policy. All managers and team leaders have the responsibility to ensure their team members are aware of and comply with this policy.
## Revision History
This policy will be revised as needed to meet the changes in business requirements, regulatory changes, and technological advancements.

## Clear Desk & Screen Policy
Version: 0.0
Policy Owner: Paul Blankley
Status: Implemented
# Clear Desk and Screen Policy
Workforce members shall avoid exposing Sensitive/Regulated Information, Restricted Information, and Confidential Information.
When Sensitive/Regulated Information, Restricted Information, and Confidential Information is not in use, all workforce members shall:
• Exit all applications where information may display on screen
• Hide and secure all physical copies of information
• Ensure that copies of information are destroyed when no longer in use
Screens for all devices used to access Regulated Information, Restricted Information, or Confidential Information must not be viewable from outside the employees immediate work area. The ability for unauthorized viewing should be avoided.
If an unauthorized person enters an area where Regulated Information, Restricted Information, or Confidential Information is present, workforce members shall take steps to conceal the information, including by:
• Turning off displays and exiting applications
• Covering physical copies of information

## Human Resource Security
Version: 0.0
Policy Owner: Paul Blankley
Status: Implemented
# Security in Job Descriptions Policy
Security roles and responsibilities must be clearly specified in all relevant job descriptions or defined in contracts or agreements.
# New Hire Communications Policy
Hiring activity must be coordinated through the Human Resources Team prior to start dates. New hires must also be communicated to the Security Team, which is responsible for role-based access across all systems at Zenlytic.
## Employee Onboarding
Zenlytic shall onboard all employees to ensure the security and privacy of all Zenlytic data and information.
The Human Resources Team shall perform professional-reference background screening on all prospective employees and any contractors that require access to Sensitive/Regulated Information. In case of contractors, screening requirements may be outlined in the contract between Zenlytic and the contractor.
The Human Resources Team shall retain background screening documentation for employees as part of employment records for 1 year.
## Disqualifying Criminal Offenses
The Human Resources Team shall initiate the background screening process before Zenlytic makes an offer of employment. A new hire may only start with Zenlytic once the screening has been completed and the candidate has been cleared by the Human Resources Team.
- Felony Convictions: Felonies often involve serious crimes, such as murder, arson, rape, burglary, or large-scale fraud. A history of felony convictions may be a significant concern when hiring for positions of trust or responsibility.
- Sexual Offenses: Individuals with convictions for sexual offenses might be disqualified for roles that involve interacting with vulnerable populations (such as children or the elderly), or for roles where they would be working in close contact with other employees or customers.
- Financial Crimes: Convictions for crimes like fraud, embezzlement, identity theft, or other financial crimes may disqualify a candidate for positions that involve handling finances or sensitive financial data.
- Violent Crimes: Convictions for violent crimes such as assault, battery, or domestic violence could potentially disqualify a candidate, particularly for roles that involve interaction with the public or where workplace safety could be a concern.
The Human Resources Team or the Security Team shall grant the new employee or contractor access to Zenlytic systems commensurate with roles and responsibilities as well as the principle of least privilege.
Any exceptions to this requirement must be specifically approved by the Security Team, and logged in a list of exceptions.
The Engineering Team shall issue devices to the employee or contractor and track issuance as described in the CC3.2.1 IT Asset Inventory. The Human Resources Team shall assign training courses based on roles to the new employee or contractor, consistent with the Security & Privacy Training Policy.
# Security & Privacy Training Policy
All employees who interact with secure resources must complete all required training components:
• When they join Zenlytic or are assigned a role with additionally required training
• At least annually after they complete the initial training
• As company circumstances change, at the direction of the Security Officer
The Security Officer is responsible for recommending to the Management Team when there exists sufficient cause to modify training or re-train employees due to operational or environmental changes.
Zenlytic shall document and retain all training records for active employees. Human Resources Team shall assign training as part of employee onboarding or when there is a change in duties that requires retraining or additional training.
The Human Resources Team shall assign training as follows:
• Basic security awareness training - All employees
# Employee Sanctions Policy
Zenlytic employees who violate the Information Security System may be subject to sanctions, which may include, but are not limited to, retraining, reassignment, separation, or referral to law enforcement. Information Security System violations are treated as security incidents, and investigations are conducted as described under the Information Security Violations Policy.
# Information Security Violations Policy
## Investigation
When a Zenlytic employee violates an Information Security requirement or policy, the Human Resources Team shall conduct an investigation by analyzing the individual's conduct to determine whether she or he actually violated an Information Security requirement or policy.
The Human Resources Team may request assistance from the Security Team, the Legal Team, and the Management Team to make that determination. Vendors in violation are subject to the Vendor Termination Policy.
## Assessment
If the Human Resources Team concludes that the individual violated an Information Security System requirement or policy, the Human Resources Team shall convene a management group to select one or more disciplinary actions.
The management group shall consist of the following:
• The workforce member's immediate manager
• The head of the workforce member's department
• Representatives from the Legal Team and the Human Resources Team
• The Security Officer
• The primary investigator of the incident
In selecting a disciplinary action, the management group shall consider the following:
• The nature and impact of the violation
• The clarity of the policies, procedures, or standards involved
• The amount and quality of the training provided to the individual
• Whether the individual has committed previous violations
• Any legal factors, if relevant
The individual may be requested to participate in parts of the assessment if/as the management group deems appropriate. The management group shall record minutes of the assessment meeting(s) and may decide to suspend the individual while the assessment is pending. Once a decision regarding action is reached, the individual's immediate manager or Human Resources Team member should communicate the decision to the individual.
## Appeal
After the management group decides on a course of action and informs the individual, the individual may appeal. If possible, the appeal should be conducted by a member of the Management Team not previously involved in the disciplinary process. The manager will review the investigation report, management assessment and decision, and any mitigating materials put forth by the individual. If the senior manager concludes that the management assessment was unreasonable or wrong, he or she may substitute their own disciplinary action, which shall be final. No further appeals are permitted.
# Mandatory Reporting Policy
## Reporting Policy
Zenlytic employees must immediately report privacy and security incidents to the Security Officer. This includes, e.g., violations of Information Security, suspicious computing events, policy violations, security weaknesses, and human resources events.
Zenlytic employees should immediately call 911 emergency services if an incident involves threat of imminent physical harm (e.g., fires, earthquakes, active shooters, etc.). Zenlytic employees should report non-urgent threats of harm or safety issues to managers, and should escalate up the chain of command if necessary.
Zenlytic employees must immediately report suspected or actual violations of criminal law to the Legal Team and the Security Officer for referral to law enforcement.
## No Retaliation Against Whistleblowers
Zenlytic shall not retaliate against, intimidate, or harass individuals who report suspected or known security events that may jeopardize the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of information, systems, or facilities.
Zenlytic shall protect the identity of individuals who report incidents unless a government agency or court of law requires the disclosure of the whistleblower’s identity. Zenlytic prohibits attempts to interfere with, prevent, or obstruct the reporting of a security or policy incident, and may discipline individuals who attempt to do so.
## External Incident Reporting Policy
To comply with legal and contractual requirements, Zenlytic may report all required security and privacy incidents to the relevant individuals, partners and authorities.
If necessary, the Security Team shall notify authorities, data subjects and partners within a reasonable time period of an incident being discovered.
The Legal Team shall review Zenlytic's legal agreements to determine whether Zenlytic must report the incident to any business partner under the terms of any agreement. The Legal Team and outside counsel (as needed) shall determine whether Zenlytic must report the incident to state regulators, data subjects, or consumer-reporting agencies under U.S. state law.
# Employee Transfers
Employee transfers or promotions must be initiated for approval and coordinated through the Human Resources Team prior to the actual date of the transition.
Logical and physical access controls for all transfers must be reassessed and, if necessary, reconfigured to align with new roles and responsibilities (in accordance with the Access Review Policy).
When an employee transfers to a new role, their membership on committees, email distribution lists and chat groups or channels, responsibilities and affiliated training, and all assets allocated to them, must be reevaluated.
# Employee Separations Policy
All employee separations must be coordinated with the Human Resources Team prior to the separation date. Contractor terminations must be coordinated with the Human Resources Team if the contract ends early. Human Resources Team shall offboard employees and contractors at or before the separation date.
The Human Resources Team or the separating employee’s manager shall timely revoke a separating employee access to Zenlytic's information, premises, and systems. The Human Resources Team or the separating employee's manager must revoke access to systems with Sensitive/Regulated Information within 24 hours of notice of the employee or contractor's departure. The Human Resources Team shall work with the Security Team to rotate shared credentials that the employee or contractor had access to. The Human Resources Team or the separating employee's manager shall log access revocation in Security Management Tasks.
The Human Resources Team shall ensure that the departing employee or contractor returns all Zenlytic-owned physical assets at termination. If access to the asset(s) is being requested by the manager/department, proper asset transfer procedures must be followed.
The Human Resources Team or the separating employee’s manager shall conduct an exit interview with the separating employee. At the meeting, the interviewer shall remind the separating employee of her or his ongoing security obligations, as described in her or his employment agreement. The interviewer shall log that the interview occurred.
# Employee Communications Policy
### Purpose
To establish clear guidelines for the appropriate, secure, and professional use of the Company’s primary communication platforms, Slack and email, so that business objectives are met without compromising confidentiality, integrity, or availability of information.
### Scope
This policy applies to all employees, contractors, interns, and third‑party partners (collectively “employees”) who create, send, receive, or store information on Company‑managed Slack workspaces and Company‑issued email accounts.
### Approved Channels
### Acceptable Use Guidelines
### a. Slack
• Use public channels whenever possible to promote transparency and knowledge‑sharing.
• Thread replies to keep conversations organized.
• Mark channels with data‑classification tags (#public, #internal, #confidential) and post content appropriate to the tag.
• Limit @channel/@here mentions to urgent, business‑critical matters.
• Archive or rename channels when projects end to maintain workspace hygiene.
• DO NOT send sensitive credentials in messages; send secure links via 1Password.
### b. Email
• Use clear, descriptive subject lines and include relevant context.
• Use distribution lists wisely; only include recipients who need to know.
• Set an out‑of‑office message when unavailable for more than one business day.
### Prohibited Uses (Both Platforms Unless Noted)

# Information Security Governance
Version: 0.0
Policy Owner: Paul Blankley
Status: Implemented
# Establishment of the Information Security Management System (ISMS)
In order to deepen Zenlytic’s commitment to security and to build trust with its customers and the wider community, Zenlytic has formally established an Information Security Management System (the “ISMS”).
The Board of Directors, Management Team, and Security Teams are dedicated to satisfying Zenlytic’s information-security requirements. To this end, they have included policies in the ISMS related to defining, achieving, and continually improving information-security objectives and the ISMS.
# ISMS Context
In order to ensure that the ISMS is suitable, adequate, and effective, Zenlytic continually analyzes the context in which it operates, including:
• the external and internal issues that Zenlytic faces; and
• the requirements of external and internal stakeholders who impact, or are impacted by, Zenlytic’s decisions.
Zenlytic's current context includes the following:
• Departmental Functions and Reporting - Zenlytic consists of the following organizational functions:
• Products and Services - Zenlytic makes the following products and services:
• External and Internal Issues - External issues are those that are outside of Zenlytic’s control. Zenlytic’s external issues include:
• Internal issues are those that are subject to Zenlytic’s control, and include the following:
• Stakeholders and their Requirements - Zenlytic’s external stakeholders and their requirements, include the following:
• Zenlytic’s internal stakeholders and their requirements, include the following:
# ISMS Scope
The scope of Zenlytic’s ISMS takes into account Zenlytic’s context, including Zenlytic’s departmental functions and reporting lines; Zenlytic’s products and services; the internal and external issues Zenlytic faces; and Zenlytic’s stakeholders (both internal and external stakeholders).
## Scope Summary
The ISMS applies to the information systems and networks, personnel, policies, and operational procedures used in the development and direct provision of Zenlytic’s products and
services.
## Inclusions
The following are within the scope of the ISMS:
• Products and services: All of Zenlytic’s products and services, as well as
• Facilities: All Zenlytic offices
• Equipment: All devices (laptops, workstations, phones and tablets), including BYOD devices that are used to store or access Zenlytic's information or information systems, are within the scope of the ISMS
• Personnel: All workforce members and contractors are within the scope of the ISMS
• ISMS Policies and procedures
## Exclusions
The following are outside the scope of the ISMS:
• Local applications not used to connect to Zenlytic’s information systems
• Remote workspaces and networks outside of Zenlytic’s control
• Client and vendor environments outside of Zenlytic’s control
# ISMS Objectives and Metrics
## ISMS Objectives
The Management Team shall establish and communicate information-security objectives and Zenlytic’s plans to evaluate and achieve them.
Zenlytic's ISMS objectives are the following:
- Comply with applicable legal and regulatory requirements at all times.
- Implement a formal risk management program.
- Implement reasonable and appropriate safeguards to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of Zenlytic information and information assets.
- Continuously improve Zenlytic’s information security posture.
## ISMS Metrics
The Management Team shall define and apply metrics to determine whether Zenlytic is achieving its ISMS objectives, and to evaluate the performance and effectiveness of the ISMS.
Zenlytic has defined metrics to measure its performance and effectiveness in achieving objectives, including:
• Zero incidents of unauthorized data access
• All employees have strong passwords
• All data is classified correctly
• All vendors go through vendor management process
• No lost sales or churned clients for InfoSec reasons
Additionally, Zenlytic has allocated the following resources to achieve its objectives this year.
• A budget for technology services that allows for best-in-class delivery of products and services
• A budget for information security (allocated to pen testing, bug bounty programs, SaaS products, vendors, and auditors)
• A Site Reliability Engineering team (assigned as part of other duties)
• A Security Steering Committee, consisting of engineering, site reliability, and technology operations team members that meets at least once per quarter
# Management Oversight
Managers at all levels are responsible for the activities and actions of their subordinates. Managers shall promote awareness of information privacy and security policies, standards, and procedures, and shall promptly report all significant changes in workforce member duties or employment status to the Security Team.
Managers shall ensure that their staff receives appropriate privacy and security awareness training commensurate to their responsibilities, as described in the Security and Privacy policy.
# Segregation of Duties
Wherever possible, conflicting duties and areas of responsibility should be segregated to reduce opportunities for unauthorized or unintentional modification or misuse of Zenlytic's systems and data. If segregation is difficult, managers shall consider other controls such as monitoring of activities, audit trails, and management supervision.
# Exception Management
Exceptions to the ISMS, including to Zenlytic's information-security policies and procedures, must be approved by the Security Officer and documented in the ISMS Exceptions list.
All exceptions to the ISMS must be approved in advance by the Security Officer. Before an exception is logged, ensure that it is approved.
The Security Officer shall log the following information in the ISMS Exceptions list:
• a brief title for the the exception;
• a detailed description of the exception;
• the name of the individual or team that authorized the exception;
• the date the exception was authorized;
• the deadline for closing the exception; and
• the state of the exception (open or closed).
# Nonconformity Management
Zenlytic shall continuously monitor for nonconformities (non-fulfillments of a requirement of the ISMS) through a number of means, including from security incidents, internal and independent audits (if applicable), and customer or workforce member complaints.
Zenlytic manages nonconformities by logging them, immediately identifying actions that need to take place to correct them, and reviewing Zenlytic’s response to them to ensure they are not repeated.
The Security Officer shall classify the nonconformity by identifying whether it is minor or major, and by describing its likely impact to the ISMS on a five-point scale (very low, low, moderate, high, very high). The Security Officer shall document this information in the ISMS Nonconformities log (The log will be stored in Zenlytic’s Product Management Tool as tickets).
When a nonconformity is identified, the Security Team shall manage it by doing the following:
• Implement Corrections to Limit the Impact of the Nonconformity
• Determine Whether Corrective Actions Should be Taken
• Plan and Implement Corrective Actions
• Assess the Effectiveness of the Corrective Actions
Finally, the Security Team shall analyze whether the corrections and corrective actions implemented indicate that the ISMS should be updated. If so, the Security Team will bring those items up at the next scheduled Management Review.
## Document Nonconformities
The Security Team shall document all identified nonconformities, as well as Zenlytic’s responses to them, in the ISMS Nonconformities. At a minimum, the following information should be included for each nonconformity:
• A description of the nonconformity
• The date the nonconformity was identified/raised
• The type of nonconformity (major or minor)
• The source of the nonconformity (e.g., internal audit)
• Who reported the nonconformity
• The provisions or requirements in the relevant frameworks that are implicated by this nonconformity
• The reactive actions/corrections implemented to limit the impact of the nonconformity
• The cause of the nonconformity
• The impact level of the nonconformity (on a five-point scale from very low to very high)
• The corrective actions taken (if any)
• The individual responsible for implementing the corrective actions
• The deadline for implementing the corrective actions
• The status of the corrective actions
• The date that the Management Team or the Security Team determines that the nonconformity is resolved
Template for use in Zenlytic’s Product Management Tool:
# Internal Audits
To ensure that the ISMS conforms to Zenlytic’s compliance requirements and is being effectively implemented and maintained, Zenlytic shall complete an internal audit at least annually. Zenlytic shall plan internal audits in order to minimize disruptions to business processes.
At least one month prior to the internal audit, the Security Officer shall select the lead auditor and audit team. The audit team should be selected to provide supplementary personnel with knowledge of modern software development practices, cloud software and delivery models, and information security.
The audit team lead shall develop the audit plan, which must include the criteria, scope, and methods of the audit. The audit plan must be retained as documented information.
The audit team should review:
• Whether the ISMS controls and processes are adequate and effective
• Whether the ISMS objectives have been fulfilled
• Compliance with Zenlytic’s information security requirements
• Whether the risk treatment plans Zenlytic develops are consistent with the risk assessment process, assessed risks, and Zenlytic's risk acceptance criteria
• Whether the inputs and outputs of Zenlytic's management review
• process are relevant and results in an effective governance check on the ISMS
• Whether management review outputs have a lasting, positive impact on Zenlytic. and the ISMS
Audit criteria shall be reviewed prior to each internal audit, and expanded or reduced as necessary.
The audit team lead shall complete the audit consistent with the audit plan. The audit team lead shall obtain the assistance of other Zenlytic workforce members as needed.
As the audit team works, results shall be documented in an audit report, which shall be retained as documented information.
Nonconformities shall be classified as major or minor, in accordance with the Nonconformity Management.
Evidence shall be retained.
The lead auditor shall deliver a draft audit report to the Management Team and the Security Officer for review and comment.
The Security Officer shall document a final audit report, which shall be retained as documented information. The Security Officer shall deliver the final audit report to the Management Team, and store it.
# Independent Audits
Zenlytic routinely performs independent evaluations of its ISMS and information
security. Zenlytic shall plan independent audits in order to minimize disruptions to business processes.
At least one month prior to the audit, the Security Officer shall select the lead auditor and audit team. The audit team should be selected to provide supplementary personnel with knowledge of modern software development practices, cloud software and delivery models, and information security.
The Security Officer shall prepare for the independent audit by ensuring that all nonconformities identified during the internal audit are resolved before the independent audit begins.
The Management Team shall plan audit requirements and activities to minimize business process disruption.
The audit team lead shall work with the audit team to complete the audit consistent with the audit plan. The audit team lead shall obtain the assistance of other Zenlytic workforce members as needed.
As the audit team works, results shall be documented in an audit report, which shall be retained as documented information.
Evidence shall be retained in the Audit Evidence archives.
The lead auditor shall deliver a draft audit report to the Management Team and the Security Officer for review and comment.
The Security Officer shall document a final audit report, which shall be retained as documented
information. The Security Officer shall deliver the final audit report to the Management Team, and store it in Audit Reports. This audit process can be part of the SOC2 certification process, which happens yearly.
# Identification of Statutory, Regulatory, and Contractual Requirements
In order to meet its obligations and manage risk, it is critical that Zenlytic understands, tracks, and complies with all relevant statutory, regulatory, and contractual requirements.
The Management Team shall ensure that the Legal and Contractual Requirements Log is updated as follows:
• the Legal Team shall update the Legal and Contractual Requirements Log to include state and federal laws relevant to information security (including privacy and data-protection laws), regulatory frameworks and requirements, and regulatory reporting requirements; and
• the Sales Team shall update the Legal and Contractual Requirements Log to include contractual requirements, including master service agreements and custom business-associate agreements.
The Legal and Contractual Requirements Log will be stored in Zenlytic’s Customer Relationship Management (CRM) software.
The Legal Team shall consult with Zenlytic's legal counsel and other external parties as needed when necessary to determine the scope or details of the requirement.
# Management Review
At least annually, the Management Team shall hold a Management Review meeting to ensure that:
• the ISMS is aligned with Zenlytic’s objectives;
• the ISMS is designed properly to meet Zenlytic’s requirements; and
• the ISMS policies and tasks are integrated into Zenlytic’s business processes, account for security incidents, and are continually improved
The Management Team shall review the status of actions from previous management reviews.
The Management Team shall identify the external and internal issues that Zenlytic faces.
The Management Team shall review the performance of the ISMS, including:
• existing nonconformities and the status of corrective actions;
• monitoring and measurement (metrics) results;
• audit results (including vendor reviews, internal-audit results, and external-audit results); and fulfillment of Zenlytic's ISMS objectives.
The Management Team shall update the stakeholders, and their requirements, identified in the ISMS Context.
The Management Team shall review feedback from the identified stakeholders.
The Management Team shall review:
• the results of the last risk assessment
• the status of the risk-treatment plan
The Management Team shall review opportunities for continual improvement to the ISMS, including new techniques, products, procedures, and best practices for operating the ISMS.
The Management Team shall decide whether changes should be made to the ISMS.
The Management Team shall document the results of the Management Review in the Management Review Minutes.
The Management Team shall update and approve the ISMS in light of decisions made during the Management Review.
# Security Projects Review
The Security Team shall hold a quarterly or greater Security Steering Committee meeting at which it shall discuss the status of the following:
• Zenlytic's security projects;
• any changes to Zenlytic's most recent risk assessment;
• the status of Zenlytic's responses to vulnerabilities; and
• any other security issues that are pending or that have been identified since the last Security Review.
# Policy Reviews and Maintenance
In order to ensure that the ISMS is suitable, adequate, and effective, Zenlytic shall review and approve the ISMS at least annually.
The team or individual assigned as the "Policy Owner" of each ISMS internal document/domain shall do the following:
• review the accuracy of the policies, tasks, and task requirements in the maintained domains;
• update the policies, tasks, and task requirements in the maintained domains as needed
The team or individual assigned as the "Owner" of each ISMS internal document shall do the following:
• review the proposed updates and edits to the policies, tasks, and task requirements in their owned domains;
• notify the Security Team of the updates.
# Control of ISMS Documents
In order to ensure the effectiveness of the ISMS, Zenlytic shall control documented information related to the ISMS as described below.
All documents that make up the ISMS must include the following information in text or metadata:
• Title
• Version number (if stored on GSuite or Notion, a log of all modifications will exist)
• Name of the document owner (the individual who drafted or edited the document)
Zenlytic prefers to version control ISMS documents when possible. Version numbers consist of a version and a release, starting with “0.0.” The version is incremented for major changes, and the release is incremented for minor changes.
Zenlytic prefers that all ISMS documents are kept in Notion when possible.
Zenlytic shall maintain the ISMS and the External ISMS Documents for at least six years.
# Reservation of Rights
Zenlytic reserves all rights under the law. Any and all rights or uses of Zenlytic's information assets that are not specifically granted by documented policies, procedures, plans, or standards are disapproved until the Security Officer approves them in writing.
# Board of Directors Oversight
The Zenlytic board of directors shall leverage their relevant expertise to provide independent oversight of Zenlytic’s development and performance of relevant controls. Board oversight shall include periodically reviewing the ISMS. Where the board of directors does not have the relevant expertise to meet their requirements, they will supplement their expertise with outside support.
The Board will periodically evaluate Zenlytic’s controls around organizational structure, reporting lines, segregation of duties, access controls, and vendor management. The Board subcommittee in charge of this review shall consist of Ryan Janssen and Paul Blankley.

# Incident Management

Policy Owner: Paul Blankley

# Incident Response Policy
The Incident Response Team shall respond to all potential or actual security or privacy incidents in accordance with the Incident Response Plan and Incident Response Playbooks.
The Incident Response Team shall respond to all incidents according to the Incident Response Playbooks for that category of incident. If no such playbook exists, the Incident Response Team shall follow the model response identified in the Incident Response Plan.
The Incident Response Lead shall ensure that all incidents are logged and archived in the Incident Response Log. Once the incident and the response are documented, the Incident Response Team shall mark the incident as closed. This will happen in Zenlytic’s Product Management Tool.
# Incident Response Training and Testing Policy
In order to ensure that Zenlytic is prepared to respond to all potential and actual security and privacy incidents, the Incident Response Team shall be trained on Zenlytic's incident response policies and plan, and shall perform incident response exercises.
The Incident Response Team shall review the following as part of training:
• the Incident Response Plan
• the Incident Response Playbooks
• the documentation logged from all incidents since the last training
## Tabletop Exercises
Tabletop exercises are “discussion-based exercises where personnel meet in a classroom setting or in breakout groups to discuss their roles during an emergency and their responses to a particular emergency situation. A facilitator presents a scenario and asks the exercise participants questions related to the scenario, which initiates a discussion among the participants of roles, responsibilities, coordination, and decision-making. A tabletop exercise is discussion-based only and does not involve deploying equipment or other resources.”
The objective of a tabletop exercise is to determine if members of the Incident Response Team can realistically walk through their critical functions during a mock incident.
To perform a tabletop exercise, the Incident Response Team shall choose at least one incident that Zenlytic will likely face in the next twelve months.
The Incident Response Team shall create a playbook for the chosen incident. At a minimum, this shall include the following information for each chosen incident:
• the date the playbook was created;
• the individual or team responsible for the playbook (the Owner);
• the internal and external resources needed to follow the playbook in a real incident;
• Phase 1: How the Incident Response Team should identify occurrence of the incident; whom the Incident Response Team should notify of the incident; and how the Incident Response Team should assess the incident;
• Phase 2: How the Incident Response Team should contain and eradicate the incident;
• Phase 3: The post-incident activity that the Incident Response Team should take, including reporting the incident if necessary, and performing after-action reviews.
The Incident Response Team may revisit and update existing playbooks as part of tabletop testing.
In addition to scheduled tabletop exercises, at least annually, the Incident Response Lead will simulate the occurrence of an incident and ensure that the Incident Response Team follows the relevant playbooks. The test incident shall be logged in the Incident Response Log.
# Concept of Operations for Incident Response
Zenlytic shall use a phased approach for the investigation and resolution of privacy and security incidents.
## Incident Response Planning
Zenlytic shall plan its response to security and privacy incidents by developing this Incident Response Plan, developing the Incident Response Playbooks (as described in the Incident Response Training and Testing Policy), and applying security controls for critical information systems.
### Business Impact Analysis
The Incident Response Team shall prioritize its responses to multiple incidents based on:
• the criticality of the affected assets; and
• the current or potential adverse effect.
### Communications
During the incident response process, the Incident Response Team shall communicate via the following methods/tools:
• Slack
• Video chat
• Phone
• Email (if necessary)
## Incident Response Phases
### Phase 1: Identification and Notification
Activation Criteria
The identification phase is focused on detecting whether an actual security or privacy incident took place. In this phase, the responder shall attempt to gain an understanding of the nature of the incident and to make a determination whether the incident is not a false positive.
Notification Procedures
If the event is not a false positive, or the responder is unable to make a determination, the responder shall notify other workforce members according to the playbook for that type of incident. If no individual is identified, the workforce member shall notify the Security Officer or the Incident Response Lead.
Assessment
Incidents and response efforts, shall be documented with:
• A ticket in Linear (or other issue tracking tool).
• (If applicable to the incident) A Postmortem (Root Cause Analysis) report
The Incident Response Team shall assess the scope and nature of the incident by reviewing the following:
• Incident name
• Incident type (e.g., availability, denial of service, unauthorized access, etc)
• An executive summary of the incident
• Severity level
• Status of the incident
• A full timeline of actions taken by all members of the Incident Response Team (this is updated through all phases of the incident)
### Phase 2: Containment and Eradication
The Incident Response Team shall contain and eradicate the incident.
Playbooks should clearly identify the steps that should be taken to limit and mitigate the effects of the compromise.
### Phase 3: Post-Incident Activity
Reporting
As applicable, the Security Officer shall report the incident to necessary parties to fulfill contractual, statutory, or other legal requirements and best practices.
Review and Prevention
After eradication and recovery of each incident, the Incident Response Team shall review the incident as well as Zenlytic’s handling of the incident. This should be fully documented in a Postmortem (Root Cause Analysis) report, along with any action items designed to mitigate or prevent such incidents in the future.

# Software Patch Management Policy
Zenlytic shall ensure that software used within the organization is consistently updated to address security vulnerabilities, improve functionality, and maintain system integrity. Zenlytic utilizes GitHub and Dependabot to automatically propose, review, and integrate software updates in a timely and secure manner.
## Patch Identification
Dependabot shall continuously monitor all software repositories hosted on GitHub to identify available software patches, updates, and security advisories relevant to Zenlytic’s software assets.
## Patch Evaluation and Prioritization
Upon identification of a proposed patch, Dependabot shall automatically create a pull request (PR) for evaluation. The Software Engineering Team shall assess each PR to determine:
• The criticality of the identified vulnerability or update
• Potential impact of the update on system stability
• Any necessary testing prior to deployment
Patches addressing high-severity vulnerabilities or critical updates shall be prioritized.
## Patch Integration and Deployment
Approved patches shall be integrated promptly after successful testing and validation. Integration occurs through Zenlytic’s established code review and continuous integration (CI/CD) processes, ensuring automated tests and manual code reviews confirm patch integrity prior to deployment.
All deployments resulting from approved Dependabot PRs shall follow the standard software release process, ensuring minimal disruption to business operations.
## Documentation and Tracking
Zenlytic shall document all patch-related activities within GitHub, capturing:
• Dependabot-generated PRs
• Reviews and approvals by the Software Engineering Team
• Successful integrations and deployments
This documentation supports transparency and auditability in patch management activities.
## Review and Compliance
The Software Engineering Lead or designated representative shall periodically review patch management activities to ensure compliance with this policy. The frequency of these reviews shall be at least quarterly.
Any deviations from the prescribed processes shall be documented, along with corresponding corrective actions.
## Training
The Software Engineering Team shall receive training on Zenlytic’s patch management policy and practices, including:
• Dependabot functionality and usage
• GitHub integration workflows
• Review and deployment procedures
Regular refresher training shall be conducted on an as needed basis on significant process changes.

## Termination Offboarding Policy
Version: 1.0
Policy Owner: Paul Blankley
Status: Implemented
The steps in detail will be covered in the offboarding section of Employee Onboarding Process 
## Overview
At Zenlytic, we recognize that employee departures are a natural part of business operations. However, they also present a risk to the security and privacy of our information, systems, and premises. Hence, a systematic and comprehensive offboarding process is necessary to mitigate these risks and ensure a smooth transition. This policy sets forth our standard procedures for the termination and offboarding of employees and contractors.
## Objective
The objective of this policy is to define the procedures to be followed when an employee or contractor separates from the company, ensuring that the company's assets, data, and systems are secure and that the separation is handled in an organized, respectful, and professional manner.
## Scope
This policy applies to all Zenlytic employees and contractors. All managers, supervisors, and team leaders are responsible for ensuring the compliance of their teams with this policy.
## Policy
- Notification of Separation: As soon as the decision to terminate an employment or contractor relationship has been made, the Human Resources Team must be notified. Contractor terminations must also be coordinated with the Human Resources Team if the contract ends early.
- Offboarding Process: The Human Resources Team is responsible for initiating and overseeing the offboarding process at or before the separation date. This includes ensuring that the departing employee or contractor returns all Zenlytic-owned physical assets.
- Revoking Access: The Human Resources Team or the separating employee’s manager is responsible for timely revoking the separating employee's access to Zenlytic's information, premises, and systems. Access to systems containing Sensitive/Regulated Information must be revoked within 24 hours of notice of the employee or contractor's departure.
- Shared Credentials: The Human Resources Team shall collaborate with the Security Team to rotate shared credentials that the separating employee or contractor had access to.
- Logging Actions: All actions related to access revocation must be logged in the Security Management Tasks.
- Asset Return and Transfer: All Zenlytic-owned physical assets in the possession of the departing employee or contractor must be returned at termination. If the manager or department requests access to the asset(s), proper asset transfer procedures must be followed.
- Exit Interview: The Human Resources Team or the separating employee's manager shall conduct an exit interview with the separating employee or contractor. The separating individual should be reminded of their ongoing security obligations as outlined in their employment or contractor agreement. The occurrence of this interview must be logged.
## Enforcement
Failure to comply with this policy may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment for existing employees. Legal action may be taken where necessary.
## Return of Assets 
Employees who are terminated will be have access revoked to all web-based systems and will return the following physical items
• Laptop
## Revision History
This policy will be reviewed and updated at least annually or whenever significant changes occur to ensure its continued relevance and effectiveness.

## Change Management Policy and Procedures
Version: 1.0
Policy Owner: Paul Blankley
Status: Implemented
## Introduction
The Change Management Plan was created for the Zenlytic in order to set expectations on how the approach to changes will be managed, what defines a change, the purpose and role of the change control board, and the overall change management process. All stakeholders will be expected to submit or request changes to Zenlytic in accordance with this Change Management Plan and all requests and submissions will follow the process detailed herein.
## Change Management Approach
The Change Management approach for Zenlytic will ensure that all proposed changes are defined, reviewed, and agreed upon so they can be properly implemented and communicated to all stakeholders. This approach will also ensure that only changes within the scope of this project are approved and implemented.
The Change Management approach is not to be confused with the Change Management Process which will be detailed later in this plan. The Change Management approach consists of three areas:
• Ensure changes are within scope and beneficial to the project
• Determine how the change will be implemented
• Manage the change as it is implemented
The Change Management process has been designed to make sure this approach is followed for all changes. By using this approach methodology, the Zenlytic Team will prevent unnecessary change from occurring and focus its resources only on beneficial changes within the project scope.
## Definitions of Change
There are several types of changes which may be requested and considered for Zenlytic. Depending on the extent and type of proposed changes, changes project documentation and the communication of these changes will be required to include any approved changes into the project plan and ensure all stakeholders are notified. Types of changes include:
• Scheduling Changes: changes which will impact the approved project schedule. These changes may require fast tracking, crashing, or re-baselining the schedule depending on the significance of the impact.
• Budget Changes: changes which will impact the approved project budget. These changes may require requesting additional funding, releasing funding which would no longer be required, or adding to project or management reserves. May require changes to the cost baseline.
• Scope Changes: changes which are necessary and impact the project’s scope which may be the result of unforeseen requirements which were not initially planned for. These changes may also impact budget and schedule. These changes may require revision to tickets, project scope statement, and other project documentation as necessary.
The project manager must ensure that any approved changes are communicated to the project stakeholders. Additionally, as changes are approved, the project manager must ensure that the changes are captured in the project documentation where necessary. These document updates must then be communicated to the project team and stakeholders as well.
## Change Control Process
The Change Control Process for Zenlytic will follow the organizational standard change process for all projects. The project manager has overall responsibility for executing the change management process for each change request.
- Identify the need for a change (Stakeholders) – Change requestor will submit a modification request to the ticket to modify in the project management tool to the owner of the ticket.
- Log change in the change request register (Project Manager) – The project manager will keep a log of all submitted change requests throughout the project’s lifecycle. This will be done in the project management tool.
- Evaluate the change (Project Manager, Team, Requestor) – The project manager will conduct a preliminary analysis on the impact of the change to risk, cost, schedule, and scope and seek clarification from team members and the change requestor.
- Obtain Decision on change request – The project manager will discuss the proposed change and decide whether or not it will be approved based on all submitted information.
- Implement change (Project Manager) – If a change is approved by the project manager, he or she will update the ticket and documentation as necessary.

## Vendor Management Policy
Version: 0.0
Policy Owner: Paul Blankley
Status: Implemented
# Purpose and Scope
• This policy defines the rules for relationships with the organization’s Information Technology (IT) vendors and partners.
• This policy applies to all IT vendors and partners who have the ability to impact the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the organization’s technology and sensitive information, or who are within the scope of the organization’s information security program.
• This policy applies to all employees and contractors that are responsible for the management and oversight of IT vendors and partners of the organization.
• This policy ensures customers are notified in the event a new third-party subprocessor is added that processes customer data.
It is the duty of CTO and CISO to ensure:
• Each vendor relationship supports the entity’s strategic plan and meets the requirements and policies;
• The entity has sufficient expertise to oversee and manage the relationship;
• The entity has evaluated prospective providers based on the scope and criticality of the outsourced services;
• The risks associated with the use of vendors for the entity’s critical operations are fully understood; and
• An appropriate oversight program is in place to monitor each vendor's risk management controls, financial condition and contractual performance.
The overall security of the organization is highly dependent on the security of its contractual relationships with its IT vendors. This policy defines requirements for effective management and oversight of such vendors from an information security perspective. The policy prescribes minimum standards a vendor must meet from an information security standpoint, including security clauses, risk assessments, service level agreements, and incident management.
# Rationale
The entity acquires services from third‐party suppliers, vendors, consultants and/or contractors (the "Vendor” or “Vendors") which involve risks similar to those that arise when these functions are performed internally by the entity. These include such risks as threats to the availability of systems used to support these transactions along with the accuracy, completeness, integrity, security, and privacy of protected information and compliance with applicable regulations.
Under contractual arrangements, risk management procedures commonly used by the entity to address these risks, are generally under the control of the vendor, rather than the entity. However, the entity continues to bear certain associated risks of financial loss, reputation damage, or other adverse consequences from actions of the vendor or the failure of the vendor to adequately manage risk.
Consequently, it is imperative for the entity to evaluate the ability of existing and prospective vendors to fulfill their contractual obligations and to prepare formal analyses of risks associated with obtaining services from, or outsourcing processing to, third parties.
## Responsibility/Ownership
The CTO and CISO shall be the owners of the Vendor Management Policy with oversight by the Security Steering Committee.
# Classifications of Vendor Criticality
During the vendor selection process, the CTO and CISO will assess the risks associated with vendor inadequacy (e.g. data confidentiality, Service Level Agreements, privacy assurances, user support, etc.). Prior to determining the risk, the entity will consider the criticality of the services and apply a ranking according to the criteria below.
• High (3) ‐ Services in this category include those considered "critical" to the entity’s operations. The entity would not be able to operate at adequate capacity without the availability of such services or deliver minimally acceptable levels of customer service.
• Medium (2) ‐ Services in this category include those considered of importance to the entity’s operations.
• Low (1) ‐ Services in this category include those considered incidental to the entity’s operations or for whom the entity would have an acceptable alternate vendor readily available or an alternative means to process.
# Risk Management
Risk management is the process of identifying, measuring, monitoring and managing risk. Risk exists whether the entity performs work internally or outsources work.
When a new procurement is initiated for a new vendor or for an existing vendor but for a new service, the procurement team requests the business owner to fill out an overview form prior to processing the purchase order. The business owner provides as much information about the vendor as available to aid in initiating the risk assessment. At a minimum, the information requested in the vendor overview form is required.
The CTO and CISO with oversight by the Security Steering Committee, will consider some or all of the following factors in evaluating the quantity of risk at the inception of an outsourcing decision. The degree to which these factors will be considered will depend on the criticality rating of the function provided by the vendor.
• Sensitivity of data accessed, protected or controlled by the vendor
• Volume of transactions
• Criticality to the business
• Strength of financial condition
• Turnover of management and employees
• Ability to maintain business continuity
• Ability to provide accurate, relevant, and timely information systems
• Experience with the function outsourced
• Reliance on subcontractors
• Location, especially if foreign based
• Redundancy and reliability of communication lines
• Location (processing and data storage)
• Dependence on third parties
• Reliability
• Security
• Scalability to accommodate future growth
# Agreements
When agreements or contracts are required between the entity and a vendor, the contract will be developed in consultation with the Legal Team.
# Vendor Contract Monitoring
The CTO and CISO will ensure vendors provide the goods and/or services in accordance with the vendor contract. Monitoring of contract performance will include but not be limited to review of the data confidentiality, Service Level Agreements, privacy assurances, user support. The program shall monitor the vendor environment including its security controls, financial strength and the impact of any external events. The amount of review and documentation needed to support vendor contract management will vary depending on the criticality and complexity of the system, process or service being outsourced. 
To increase monitoring effectiveness, the CTO and CISO shall periodically, but at least annually, rank vendor relationships according to risk to determine which vendors require closer monitoring. The CTO and CISO with oversight by the Security Steering Committee, shall base the rankings on the residual risk of the relationship after analyzing the quantity of risk relative to the controls over those risks. Relationships with higher risk ratings should receive more frequent and stringent monitoring for due diligence, performance (financial and or operational) and independent control validation reviews.

## Testing Minutes
### 1. Purpose and Scope
The purpose of this Business Continuity Plan (BCP) is to ensure that our Business Intelligence (BI) platform can continue to operate during and after a disruptive event. This plan outlines the steps for preparedness, response, and recovery, ensuring minimal disruption to critical BI services such as data processing, reporting, and analytics. It applies to all systems, personnel, and processes supporting the platform.
### 2. Objectives
• Maintain availability of critical BI services with minimal downtime.
• Protect sensitive data and ensure data integrity.
• Provide clear roles, responsibilities, and actions for team members in the event of a disruption.
• Ensure a swift recovery of services to meet Recovery Time Objectives (RTO) and Recovery Point Objectives (RPO).
### 3. Risk Assessment and Business Impact Analysis (BIA)
A detailed risk assessment and BIA have been conducted to identify potential risks and their impacts on the BI platform. Key risks include, but are not limited to:
• Software issues or bugs
• Vendor failures
• Network outages
• Cybersecurity attacks (DDoS, etc.)
Risks are fully outlined in the CC1.2.2 Risk Assessment document.
Impact on Business Operations: Downtime of the BI platform could result in lost business insights, reduced operational efficiency, and missed business opportunities.
### 4. Recovery Time Objectives (RTO) and Recovery Point Objectives (RPO)
• Recovery Time Objectives (RTO): The BI platform must be restored within 4 hours of a disruption for critical services.
• Recovery Point Objectives (RPO): Data loss must not exceed 15 minutes in the event of a disruption.
### 5. Key Components of the BI Platform
• Cloud infrastructure: Hosted primarily on Amazon Web Services (AWS).
• Data storage: All data is backed up using native AWS RDS features. This policy is documented in our CC7.2.2 Database Backup Policy 
### 6. Business Continuity Strategies
6.1 High Availability and Redundancy
• Database Failover: RDS instances for databases have multi-AZ replication enabled to automatically failover in the event of failure.
• Auto-scaling: AWS ECS is configured for auto-scaling, ensuring that enough resources are available during peak loads or disruptions.
6.2 Backup and Recovery
• Data Backups: Automated backups are taken of all critical data using AWS RDS, with replication to multiple AWS regions. Backup frequency is every 5 minutes to meet the RPO
6.3 Incident Response Plan
• Incident Detection: 24/7 monitoring through AWS CloudWatch and GuardDuty. Alerts are configured for anomalies such as unusual traffic, latency, or failed services.
• Incident Escalation: Incidents are escalated based on severity. 
• Response Procedures: In the event of a disruption:
### 7. Communication Plan
In the event of a disruption, the following communication steps will be followed:
• Internal Communication: Incident response team is immediately notified via Slack and email. Regular updates on the status of the disruption and recovery process will be provided.
• Customer Communication: In case of significant outages that invoke the BCP (exceeding 4 hours or lost customer data), affected customers will be notified via email within 24 hours of the event, with updates provided as available.
### 8. Testing and Maintenance
• Testing Schedule: The Business Continuity Plan will be tested annually to ensure that all procedures are up-to-date and effective. Testing will include failover simulations, backup restoration, and incident response drills.
• Plan Review: The BCP will be reviewed quarterly, or after a significant incident, to incorporate lessons learned, changes in infrastructure, or updates in business operations.
• Training: All relevant personnel will undergo BCP training annually, covering roles, responsibilities, and response procedures.
### 9. Roles and Responsibilities
• Incident Commander: Coordinates the overall incident response, communication, and recovery efforts.
• DevOps Team: Responsible for infrastructure restoration, failover, and ensuring system availability.
• Database Administrators: Restore database services and ensure data integrity post-recovery.
• Communications Lead: Responsible for internal and external communication during an incident.
### 10. Continuous Improvement
After each incident or disruption, a post-incident review will be conducted to:
• Analyze the root cause of the disruption.
• Evaluate the effectiveness of the BCP response.
• Identify areas for improvement and update the BCP accordingly.
## 11. Compliance
All staff are required to comply with this Business Continuity Plan. Non-compliance may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment.

This is a high‑impact, hands‑on role for a finance leader who is ready to roll up their sleeves and shape the future of AI‑powered analytics.
We move fast. The AI and analytics space is evolving daily, and we’re scaling in stride. If you spent the last several years sharpening your analytical edge at a New York investment bank and are now craving an operational role in tech, we’d love to meet you.

• Manage outsourced accounting: Direct and optimize our external bookkeeping & accounting firm; drive process standardization, SLA adherence, and cost efficiency.
• Own board & fundraising materials: Develop investor‑grade financial statements, KPI definitions, fundraising decks, and board packages that tell our growth story with clarity and precision.
• Build financial models & forecasts: Maintain dynamic SaaS metrics models; run scenario analyses to guide strategic planning and cash‑burn management.
• Run financial operations: Oversee AP/AR, payroll, cash‑flow management, vendor contracts, and expense policies; establish internal controls and automate workflows where possible.
• Partner cross‑functionally: Advise founders and functional leads on budgeting, headcount planning, and ROI.
• Ensure compliance: Coordinate tax filings, audits, and regulatory requirements; maintain a strong control environment as we scale.
## What you’ll bring
• 5+ years of progressive finance or accounting experience, including 3+ years in investment banking, corporate banking, or capital markets at a leading bank.
• Expert‑level proficiency in Excel and familiarity with modern accounting or ERP systems (e.g. QuickBooks).
• Deep understanding of SaaS metrics (ARR, NRR, CAC, LTV) and unit‑economics modeling.
• Proven ability to craft compelling investor materials and present to boards, VCs, and executive leadership.
• Strong project‑management skills, a bias toward action, and comfort with ambiguity and rapid change.
## Additional Information
Zenlytic is a remote‑first company. Team members may work from anywhere in the United States. For those who prefer an office environment, we maintain space in Midtown Manhattan.
Visa Sponsorship: U.S. citizens and those authorized to work in the U.S. are encouraged to apply. Please note that this position is not eligible for visa sponsorship.
