pages.title: SOC2 Background
pages.content:
Zenlytic is a self-serve analytics tool that aims to simplify the process of data exploration and decision-making through its intuitive interface and powerful AI capabilities. This tool is designed to answer data-related questions in seconds, thereby reducing reliance on a time-strapped analytics team.
## Services provided

Zenlytic provides an interface for exploring and querying data, combined with dashboards for visualization and a LLM-powered chatbot named Zöe for interactive, natural language data analysis. Zenlytic also uses advanced semantic data modeling to make it easier for end-users to explore data.
Zenlytic’s core services provide the following capabilities:
• Data ingestion through secure Data Warehouse connections 
• Automated data cleaning and normalization
• Natural language data summaries and insights generated from large language models
• Data visualization tools for exploring insights
• Data access controls and security
Zenlytic’s services are designed to provide automated, scalable data analysis to clients. The natural language insights generated by Zenlytic’s large language models make data more accessible to clients.
## Principal Service Commitments and System Requirements
Zenlytic designs its methodologies and practices in relation to its business intelligence services to achieve its objectives for these services. The objectives are shaped by the service commitments that Zenlytic makes to its clients, the regulatory landscape governing the provision of business intelligence services, and the financial, operational, and compliance benchmarks that Zenlytic has put in place. Zenlytic's business intelligence services comply with various data protection regulations, such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), as well as local data protection laws in the regions where Zenlytic operates.
Service commitments regarding security to user entities are thoroughly documented and communicated through Service Level Agreements (SLAs) and other client agreements, as well as in the description of the service offering available online. These security commitments are standardized and encompass, but are not restricted to, the following elements:
• Security principles ingrained within the essential designs of the business intelligence tool that allow users to access information pertinent to their role in the system, while preventing them from accessing data not required for their function.
• Utilization of encryption technologies to safeguard client data, both in transit and at rest.
Zenlytic sets up operational requirements that help fulfill security commitments, applicable laws and regulations, and other system requirements. These requirements are expressed in Zenlytic's system policies and procedures, system design documentation, and contracts with clients. Information security policies outline a company-wide approach to the protection of systems and data. This includes policies around how the service is designed and developed, how the system is operated, how internal business systems and networks are managed, and how employees are recruited and trained. In addition to these policies, standard operating procedures have been documented to provide guidance on executing specific manual and automated processes vital for the operation and development of the business intelligence tool.
## Components of the System Used to Provide the Services
### Infrastructure
Zenlytic uses AWS as its cloud provider. It runs Docker containers on the AWS ECS service, uses AWS RDS for its database, AWS Parameter Store for environment variables, and leverages AWS S3 for storing files. Zenlytic also uses AWS CloudWatch for monitoring and alerting and AWS Lambda for serverless computing. Zenlytic’s comprehensive architecture diagram is below: 
### Software
Zenlytic's back end is written in Python, and its front end is built with React. It also uses several other technologies, including Docker for containerization and AWS services for cloud computing and storage.
Zenlytic's software infrastructure is composed of a Python Flask backend and a React frontend, developed and maintained by Zenlytic's in-house software engineering team. This software stack is deployed on Amazon Web Services (AWS) and is designed to provide service for Zenlytic's clientele, which includes corporations, governments, and other organizations (user entities) in need of efficient business intelligence solutions. Zenlytic's software is proprietary and not sold on the open market.
Zenlytic's system processes information in real-time. The information is immediately stored in the database and is accessible for a variety of operational uses, including data analysis, report generation, and tracking of user interactions.
The Zenlytic interface is a multiuser, web-based application that facilitates the flow of information between Zenlytic and its corporate clients. This interface allows clients to input and retrieve specific information about their data analysis needs and provides performance reports to help manage their usage of Zenlytic's services. To access the site, corporations must register and provide certain required information, such as roles and permissions desired and connection information for their data warehouse.
The Zenlytic interface is provided as a service to Zenlytic's clients. This interface allows them to monitor basic statistics of their usage and resolve simple queries. Summary reports of data volume, queries, and utilization are available in addition to detailed reports for individual data analyses, single queries, and user activity.
### Data
Data, as defined by Zenlytic, consists of the following:
• Production Database: This is the central data storage for Zenlytic, containing all the data points collected from various sources and used for processing. It includes structured and unstructured data, user interactions, and permissions.
• Metric Definitions: These are definitions of measurements that Zenlytic uses to analyze performance or gauge the value delivered by the tool. Metrics could include conversion definitions, data processing times, data accuracy scores, and system performance indicators. These are stored in a git repo.
• Output Reports: These are the results generated from Zenlytic's data processing and analysis. It includes data analysis reports, visualizations, and other forms of output that are provided to the user.
• System Files: These include files that are necessary for the system's operation, such as configuration files, system logs, and error logs. These are stored in AWS S3 and Parameter Store.
• Error Logs: These logs contain records of any errors or issues that occur during the operation of Zenlytic's system. They are used to troubleshoot problems and improve system performance. These are stored securely in AWS Cloudwatch and Sentry.
All data processing initiates with the receipt of a data analysis or report generation request from users or client entities. After the data processing is completed, feedback and usage information is logged. Reports generated by Zenlytic are made available securely via electronic PDF, comma-delimited value file exports, or directly from the various web interfaces, depending on the user's role and privileges.
### People
Zenlytic has 11 employees and those staff are in the following areas:
• Customer Success
• Sales
• Marketing
• Engineering
• Design
### Processes and Procedures
Zenlytic's management has formulated and disseminated procedures to limit logical access to its business intelligence platform. These procedures are reviewed and updated annually under the authorization of senior management. The procedures cover the following key security life cycle areas:
• Data Classification: This involves organizing data based on its level of sensitivity, value, and criticality. It covers data at rest (stored data), in motion (data being transferred), and output (resultant data).
• Information Categorization: This refers to the sorting and labeling of data based on factors such as its origin, nature, and intended use.
• Business Impact Assessment: This involves evaluating the potential effects on business operations and objectives that might result from different security strategies.
• Security Controls Selection and Implementation: This includes the process of choosing, documenting, and deploying appropriate security measures to safeguard data and systems.
• Security Control Self-Assessments: Zenlytic conducts annual self-assessments to evaluate the effectiveness of its security controls.
• Access Management: This involves authorizing, modifying, and terminating access to the information system, ensuring that only authorized personnel can access sensitive data and systems.
• Security Monitoring: This includes regular surveillance of security controls to detect any anomalies or potential breaches.
• Role-based Access Control: This involves managing user access and privileges based on their roles within the organization.
• Security System Maintenance: This includes the upkeep and support of the security system, as well as the provision for necessary backup and offline storage.
• Incident Response: Zenlytic has procedures in place for responding to security incidents promptly and effectively.
• Restricted Access Maintenance: Zenlytic maintains restricted access to system configurations, super user functionality, master passwords, powerful utilities, and security devices such as firewalls to ensure only authorized personnel have access to these sensitive aspects of the system.
## Relevant Aspects of the Control Environment, Risk Assessment Process, Information and Communication, and Monitoring
### Control Environment
Management Philosophy
Zenlytic's control environment mirrors the management's philosophy highlighting the significance of securing data and information related to business intelligence and analytics. The Security Steering Committee of Zenlytic meets quarterly and reports to the board annually. This committee, guided by the Zenlytic board, supervises the company's security activities. The members of this committee represent each business line and are entrusted with setting up comprehensive security policies and procedures for Zenlytic. Security's importance is underscored within Zenlytic through the formulation and communication of these policies and procedures, backed by investment in resources and personnel to execute the policies. Zenlytic, in designing its controls, considers their relevance to meet pertinent trust criteria.
Security Management
Zenlytic boasts a dedicated information security committee, which includes a security officer. They are responsible for overseeing information security across the organization. As members of the Security Steering Committee, they maintain security credentials and are obliged to annually review the information security policies. Their responsibilities encompass the development, maintenance, and enforcement of Zenlytic's information security policies. The information security policy is reviewed annually by the security officer, CTO, and CEO, and it is endorsed by the Security Steering Committee.
As the information security team safeguards security, they monitor known incidents and patches along with the results from recent vulnerability assessments. They address necessary modifications to policies and procedures, which can include a reclassification of data, a reassessment of risk, modifications in incident response plans, and a verification of responsibilities for authorizing and monitoring accesses.
During annual security training and awareness programs, the management ensures the latest security policies are communicated, and the written job descriptions for security management are clarified.
Moreover, the management is responsible for ensuring that business associate agreements are current for third parties and for revising the annual IT risk assessment.
Security Policies
Zenlytic has put the following security policies and related processes into place:
• Data classification and business impact assessment
• Selection, documentation, and implementation of security controls
• Assessment of security controls
• User access authorization and provisioning
• Revocation of user access
• Monitoring of security controls
• Security management
Zenlytic has implemented an application to support these policies and enhance the workflow and approval process. This application enables tracking of:
• Changes to data classification
• Additions, modifications, or deletions of users
• Changes to authority levels in access approvals
• Tests of new security components before installation
• Reviews of significant security monitoring events.
Change Management
Zenlytic's Change Management Plan establishes the approach to managing changes, defining a change, the function of the change control board, and the overall change management process. The Change Management approach ensures that all proposed changes are defined, reviewed, agreed upon, and appropriately implemented, focusing only on beneficial changes within the project scope. Changes may involve scheduling, budget, or scope, each of which requires different procedures and potential adjustments to project plans and communication strategies. The change control process follows the organization's standard process, with the project manager being responsible for executing the change management process for each change request. This process involves identifying the need for a change, logging the change, evaluating it, making a decision based on the submitted information, and implementing the change if approved.
Data Security and Backups
Zenlytic's data security measures are focused on consistent database backups (every 5 minutes) and the constant use of encryption to protect key data assets. It should be noted that Zenlytic operates on Amazon Web Services, a platform known for its robust security features.
Risk Assessment
Zenlytic's Risk Assessment outlines the processes for maintaining an up-to-date list of risks, creating or updating a risk register, and selecting risk treatments. The policy mandates the Security Team to regularly review information sources related to information security threats and risks, including AWS, OpenAI, Anthropic, Algolia, and Github.
The Security Officer is responsible for updating the risk register based on threats that currently affect Zenlytic. This includes risks arising from changes in Zenlytic's operational security, external environment, business model, leadership, systems and technology, as well as vendors and partners.
The risk update process involves four steps: updating the Risk Management Framework, determining the risk tolerance curve, grading the previous assessment, and conducting a new risk assessment. The risk tolerance curve is defined by estimating the dollar amounts that Zenlytic can afford to lose at different certainty levels.
Once the risk assessment results are evaluated, the Security Officer selects treatment actions for each risk. Treatment options include accepting the risk, mitigating it, avoiding it, transferring it, or sharing it. For risks that are to be mitigated, the Security Officer ensures the implementation of a security control that will reduce the likelihood of the risk.
The Risk Management Framework includes goals for the risk assessment, a threat model detailing which threats Zenlytic is subject to, and a risk model for assessing risk. Zenlytic's threat model includes a number of threat sources, while the risk model identifies risk tolerance and compares it to expected losses due to threats faced.
Zenlytic's risk acceptance criteria are estimated prior to each risk assessment, and risks are framed in terms of risk statements that identify threat events, the likelihood of occurrence, and intervals that estimate the likely impact caused by the threat events.

pages.title: Zoë Architecture
pages.content:
Zoë operates with an Agentic architecture. This means that at each step of the question-answering process, the LLM chooses between calling a tool in its set of tools or responding directly to the user. 
If the LLM chooses to call a tool, Zenlytic will run the tool and show the results to the LLM. The LLM will then make a decision on whether it wants to call another tool or respond directly to the user. This process continues until the LLM responds directly to the user.
A high-level diagram of this workflow looks like this:
## Question Answering Process
To be more specific on the set of tools that Zoë uses and when she uses them, let’s look at a more complicated question flow that involves a wider range of tools used. 
- User asks a question “Can you show me gross revenue by product YTD and tell me which product had the highest growth from last YTD to this YTD?”
- Zoë passes that question to the LLM which determines it wants to use the search fields tool. It queries the search fields tool with the search terms “gross revenue”, “ytd”, “product”.
- Zoë executes the tool itself, and returns matching fields like order_lines.total_gross_revenue, order_lines.order_date, and products.product_title, along with their additional metadata and SQL definitions.
- Zoë structures the SQL she wants to use from the metadata into a tool call to the LLM, and the LLM determines that it wants to use the run a query tool. It calls the run a query tool with SQL referencing the field definitions that it saw in the search fields tool response.
- Zoë compiles the arguments the LLM passes into SQL using the Clarity Engine, and executes that SQL query on the customer’s warehouse.
- Zoë passes the result of the tool call (the data from the query run on the warehouse) to the LLM and the LLM determines that it wants to use the code interpreter tool to calculate the percentage change from last YTD  to this YTD. The LLM writes the code it wants to execute on top of the query results it sees.
- Zoë executes the code it received as part of the tool call for code interpreter in an isolated sandbox environment. 
- Zoë passes the result of the code interpreter execution to the LLM, and the LLM determines it wants to respond to the user directly and end the iteration process. The LLM responds with text summarizing the results of the conversation thus far.
- Zoë passes that summarization to the user (including the previously used tool calls and results), answering their question.

pages.content:
### How do you connect to the data warehouse?
• Zenlytic uses database credentials to connect to and run SQL queries on your data warehouse. Zenlytic does NOT index any whole tables or copy data from your system to ours. We create a SQL query on the fly based on metadata stored in git and connected to Zenlytic and run that query on your data warehouse.
### Do you cache my data?
• We do. We use Redis to cache query results, but never the underlying tables in the warehouse. For example, if you ask for revenue daily, we will run a query to produce the data needed to show you that plot and cache the data that shows up on the plot so the next time that question is asked, it hits the cache instead of running a duplicative query on your warehouse. Note: you can configure the cache expiry time or disable the cache entirely if you wish. 
### How do you initialize the semantic layer?
• We use solely metadata from information_schema in your warehouse to create the semantic layer. The semantic layer itself is a collection of yaml files that are stored in a git repo, which is connected to Zenlytic via an SSH key pair 
• One other (optional) feature we offer is the ability to tag a field as searchable which tells our system to index the unique values in that column. This is useful for columns like status which contain values like Fulfilled or Cancelled, so Zoë can answer questions like “how many cancelled orders did we have last week?” Only fields with searchable: true tagged explicitly will be indexed (and only the unique values of the column will be indexed).
### How does the data flow from question to Zoë to answer?
- We use your information_schema tables to get the metadata to create the semantic layer. You then tag which fields you want us to index, and add any nuance in how to use which fields
- We pass that metadata to Zoe who will use it to make the decision on which fields to use in which combinations to best answer your question. That selection will be compiled into a SQL query, which we will run on your data warehouse.
- We will take that result, pick a default plot, and show the result to Zoe for summarization and synthesis.
- Results can then be added to dashboards and scheduled for delivery, or shared between users (who both have permissions to access the underlying data)
### What data do you pull from our system to run the solution in Zenlytic SaaS? Do you pull the metadata and view/table definitions/relationships ONLY to create the semantic layer inside of Zenlytic, and DO NOT PULL ANY datasets housed inside of our Snowflake tables into your environment?
- To create the semantic layer we use just metadata from information_schema tables, and we never, under any circumstances, pull raw tables from your warehouse and replicate them in our system. We create SQL queries on the fly as indicated by selections in the UI either by users or by Zoë and run those queries on your warehouse.
- We also offer the (optional) ability to tag fields like a “status” or “type” so we index the unique values of those columns and show them to Zoë to improve her ability to answer questions
- If its only the metadata and relationships being pulled, then when the prompts are fired, LLMs will evaluate the prompts, and access the semantic layer to produce the results, but at this time, during runtime, don’t you pull our data or do you push all the data processing inside snowflake to retrieve only the results and then pass it onto the presentation layer?
### Can you clarify the orchestration of the prompt to response in detail to essentially clarify how our data is used and how our core business data can be protected at rest and in transit (if being pulled).
- We use your information_schema tables to get the metadata to create the semantic layer. You then tag which fields you want us to index, and add any nuance in how to use which fields
- We pass that metadata to Zoe who will use it to make the decision on which fields to use in which combinations to best answer your question. That selection will be compiled into a SQL query, which we will run on your data warehouse.
- We will take that result, pick a default plot, and show the result to Zoe for summarization and synthesis.
- Results can then be added to dashboards and scheduled for delivery, or shared between users (who both have permissions to access the underlying data)

• We run primarily on AWS, but we run one tangential service on Azure.

• All cloud providers run in US East 1, except for our EU infra, which is wholly separate and runs in EU Central 1

### Introduction
The overarching goal of Zenlytic’s product vision is to provide every business user in an enterprise with a trustworthy and competent data analyst. This data analyst would have access to all of the internal enterprise data that the business user has access to; it could make sense of the data, answer questions about the data, and create visuals, documents, and presentations for the user. It would go beyond just reporting about internal data to creating predictions and recommendations. Further, the analyst would be capable of deep analysis and could derive root causes of events and recommend preventive actions. In short, it would be an aide capable of performing at the highest levels of intelligence.
The purpose of this document is to outline the technical vision for the major components of the core backend, in support of  Zenlytic’s product vision.
### Assumptions
To start with, we assume that our customers are enterprises and not consumers. Different enterprises have different infrastructures, and we assume that they will need integrations with some combinations of the following systems:
- Datastores - for starters, SQL datastores, but eventually other data stores
- User management systems, such as directory providers
- Cloud providers - for now AWS but eventually Azure and GCP
- Security systems (?)
- Communication systems - Slack, Teams, email, etc.
- Unstructured data sources - Google drive, Slack/Teams, email, OneDrive
We assume that our product will be a SaaS and not a desktop app. We also assume that our product will be accessible via the browser, mobile web and API.
### Overarching Guideline
Think modularly, shy away from one-off features, try to bucket functionally-related features into components, make components modular with well-defined interfaces (take inspiration from OO programming), plan for component testability and monitoring, think long-term but build scrappily, feature-by-feature based on demand.
To determine whether it’s worth modularizing existing code, use the max(2 hours, 10% of total effort) function as the guiding threshold. If it would add more than the larger of 2 hours and 10% to your project timeline to implement a feature as part of an existing component or to componentize it, it’s probably best to just implement it as a 1-off for now. Things like added maintainability can raise that threshold, while things like security or reliability risks can lower it. Use your judgment and, if in doubt, run it by leadership.

pages.title: Technical Vision - Agentic System
pages.content:
# I. Introduction
The overarching goal of Zenlytic’s product vision is to provide every business user in an enterprise with a trustworthy and competent data analyst. This data analyst would have access to all of the internal enterprise data that the business user has access to; it could make sense of the data, answer questions about the data, and create visuals, documents, and presentations for the user. It would go beyond just reporting about internal data to creating predictions and recommendations. Further, the analyst would be capable of deep analysis and could derive root causes of events and recommend preventive actions. In short, it would be an aide capable of performing at the highest levels of intelligence.
The purpose of this document is to outline the technical vision for the agentic system,  in support of  Zenlytic’s product vision.
### Assumptions
- LLMs will massively improve over time and get significantly better at
- LLM response quality improves with context quality
# II. Overarching Guideline
We aspire to achieve greater than human-level accuracy and maximum speed in fulfilling user requests. To achieve such accuracy, our starting assumption is that mimicking the process by which human intelligence answers questions will be fast and accurate. Such a process is roughly a breadth-first check with a ranked result and then depth-first by ranking in which each tool used by an LLM to answer the query is responsible for giving back the best response (tool behavior is similar). We may find that there are more optimal processes given that LLMs may not be as computationally constrained as humans. Over time, the differentiating value we bring will come from recognizing deep patterns in data. Since LLMs will get better and better at recognizing patterns in the corpus they are trained on, our differentiation will come from extending that recognition to the private data of each of our customers. The thinking is that we will build up a deep model or network that sits between the customer data and LLMs.
## Our value propositions
- Explainability
- Consistency
# III. Current Agent Architecture
At the core of the Zenlytic agent is an iterative loop. What this means is that when a user makes a request to Zenlytic, internally, we may spend time researching and comprehending the data from the database to answer the user’s request before sending back a response to the user. Conceptually, this back and forth can be thought of as an iteration of the initial request, within the initial request.
In the main (outermost) iteration, the user request is sent to the LLM with the full system prompt. The system prompt contains details about the tools available to the LLM to help fulfill the user’s request. The LLM responds with instructions for the agent on which tools to use and what parameters to call the tool with. The results of the tool call are sent back to the LLM. The LLM can respond to the agent with more tool calls, or it can conclude that the user’s request has been fulfilled satisfactorily.
In the case of a single loop, therefore, a user message to the agent results in an initial request to the LLM, a response from the LLM with instructions about making a tool call, results from the tool call sent back to the LLM, and a final response from the LLM which is forwarded to the user.
In more complex cases, a single user message may result in multiple back-and-forths between the agent and the LLM before the final response to the user. For example, the user request, “sales by month,” results in 2 iterations (main iteration, search iteration) as depicted in the following diagram:
More complex queries, or incorrect responses from the LLM, such as hallucinated column names for the data tool, for example, can result in multiple back-and-forths between the system and the LLM before the final response to the user. The data tool, for example, may respond back to the LLM, which may send a modified request, etc.
While the above diagram is a flow diagram, the corresponding system components can be visualized below.
This visualization introduces the concept of a master agent and sub-agents, which, for all intents and purposes, are just tools. This is a very simple diagram of a multi-agent system - it is really just a single agent with tools called sub-agents.
# IV. New Agent Architecture
## Agent Architecture Phase 1 (2025 Q2)
### Introducing Context
To make Zoë more than just a conversational agent, Zoë needs access to high quality context similar to how a human data analyst needs. Context is defined to be information gathered either implicitly or explicitly from user’s interaction with Zenlytic in general. 
This combined with the assumption that LLM providers will continue to roll-out LLMs with larger context-window and better instruction following, we need to have the infrastructure in place to provide high quality context to the LLM to improve our user’s experience.
Context Dimensions
- Workspace-level context
- User-level context
- Conversation context
Technical implementation detail:
### Creating Specialized Agents
To realize the value of a multi-agent system, however, the concept of sub-agent has to be further developed. Sub-agents can't be simple tools, but should share a common interface with the rest of our software components. They can be agents in their own right. Expanding this concept leads to the diagram below. It is similar to the basic multi-agent diagram except that it distinguishes between tools and sub-agents. In this system, tools refer to deterministic code, such as a search query against an index or a SQL query against a datastore. Sub-agents, on the other hand, are agents that may have multiple tools and multiple sub-agents nested within them.

The central concept is whether there is a model outside the LLM that decides what tool or subagent to route LLM responses to and whether this model is tuned using backprop.
Regardless, the concept of sub-agents is just one of modularization and parallelization. A tool implemented as a sub-agent can be developed and improved in isolation from the master agent. The prompt from a sub-agent to the LLM can have a smaller, more precise context, allowing the LLM to respond with a more accurate response than had it been given a larger context. Sub-agents can be tuned to use multiple tools in sequence or in parallel and blend the results before sending them back to the LLM.

pages.title: Agent core EDA structure
pages.content:
As part of the new agent structure, we will be leveraging core components of Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) to increase: 
• flexibility
• adaptability
• replay-ability
# Strengths of EDA
Strengths of EDA that we want to bring to our core agent logic
• each event represents a unit of “fact”
• events are stored in event brokers (not to be confused with message brokers)
• the event broker is an append-only log
• events are produced by a producer and consumed by multiple consumers. Consumers do not need to know the existence of other consumers. 
• EventRecords can be created either through application code or converting an existing table. (table-stream duality)
## A quick re-visit of the different types of events
Un-keyed Event
Represents a single statement of fact
• Examples
Entity Keyed Event
Represents a single statement of fact keyed on a unique entity ID with the purpose of constructing an entity.
• Examples
Keyed Event
Represents a single statement of fact keyed on a unique ID but is not tied to an entity used to reconstruct a state
• Examples
# How do these strengths apply to the agent structure?
In our application, most events will be Keyed Events with the following purposes:
• serve as instructions that agents pass around to each other
• serve as instructions within an agent for multi-turn thinking process
• serve as the basis to project into a context state that is used by agents
## Events as inter-agent instructions
Think of instructions as an edge in a directional graph, with each node representing the agent to invoke. 
<add diagram here>
## Events as thinking steps
<TODO>
## Events as basis
To form a “state”, whether it is a JSON object or a table, all we need to do is to replay a subset of EntityRecords, in order. 
The projected “state” is the source-of-truth for the bounded context.
As long as we capture each EventRecord at a fine-grained level so that the collection of EventRecords spans the full space we care about (their field matrix has full rank), we can express any desired state as a linear combination of those events.
## Our Implementation
• we’re relying on existing Postgres infrastructure to imitate an event broker
• A table does not natively support “append-only log” so we rely on application code to prevent modifying or deleting existing rows.
# What are the real features in our application?
## Agents leveraging memory
<TODO>
On a workspace level, user level, conversation level and agent level
# What do we gain from this structure?
## Flexibility
• The producer of EventRecords does not need to know how other consumer services are going to use it. Consumer services only need to maintain the projected state within its own boundary context. 
• In a CRUD based architecture, we would need to know the entry location for creating a new entity. 
## Replay-ability
There are two types of replays. 
Replaying user messages on new code
This is useful when we want to verify quality change in production data before officially rolling it out to users. Code-change examples that will affect quality
• add new LLM provider (ex: Gemini) or version (Claude-4)
• tweak a system prompt and make sure the problem is fixed without degrading other
• update tool implementation
Replaying old user-assistant messages from root up to a cut-off point
Having replay-ability means we get out-of-the-box solution for features:
• Message threading
• Edit message in the middle of a conversation
• A/B testing
## Adaptability
Adapt to fast roll-outs of new LLM API functionalities
Being able to adapt to the speed the LLM providers are updating their API is crucial for us and we cannot rely on a single canonical format to send requests to these APIs. In fact, we have observed discrepancies or nuances of each LLM and added ad-hoc fixes.
• Claude doesn’t allow ending a conversation with a tool message
• Gemini doesn’t support recursive tool schema
• OpenAI releases a new response API that doesn’t conform to the old Completion API
It’s true that there are services or libraries like LiteLLM that takes in a canonical format and then run the transformation before requesting the native APIs. And it did allow us to move fast and rollout new models when we have a single agent.
However, if we rely on a 3rd party service/library like LiteLLM, we will always be restricted by the speed at which they release the transformations.
Best case, we add a bunch of if statements and ad-hoc logic.
Worst case, we miss out on new functionality rollouts such as:
• Claude offering prompt caching
• OpenAI offers fine-tuning
• OpenAI has reasoning efforts while Gemini offers a “thinking budget” parameter
A longer discussion.<TODO: Add link here>
With events, we can start emitting new events in a new schema with a new transformation layer (adaptor). And only consumers who need this new version call on the new adaptor. Any consumers that doesn’t need the new feature will continue to call the V1 adaptor. 
This means we can quickly experiment a new LLM provider feature without worrying how it would affect the rest of the application.
In a CRUD-based structure, every time a provider adds a new feature, we must alter the message table to add columns (or expand a JSON column). For any non-nullable field, we need a backfill strategy or default values. The biggest issue is that we have to check all downstream implications. 
Note: It is still very possible to solve this issue by adding a version column to the table. In fact, because we currently rely on a Postgres table as an event persistent storage, this is exactly how it’s implemented right now. See [We don’t have a schema registry] section for more discussion.
Make constructing context simpler to iterate
<TODO: Add examples here>
Example: 
Another migration option for the projected states
Normally, when there is an update to a table schema, we would need to perform a table migration. 
If the schema change is strictly on the projected state, we also have a separate option of just replaying the same subset of EventRecords with a new processing logic. 
Note: A schema change on the EventRecord itself is a separate issue. 
# What are some things that we need to be cautious with this new structure? 
## Strict control over versions
Producer
• All event records should have a version and record_type tied to it. 
• The EventRecords should be an append-only list. We’re currently using a Postgres database as a replacement for a true event broker like Kafka. Postgres doesn’t natively block updates and deletes so we need to be careful to stay true to the append-only list. We will lose replay-ability if we somehow update and delete the EventRecords
• Note: Compaction can be implemented through update and delete, but it’s a different concept from a CRUD-based update/delete. We should only run compaction if it’s strictly necessary.
Consumers
• Consumers should always filter for EventRecords with the record_type and version combination that they can handle. 
• All processors should have logic to check if there are supported record_type with a newer version. In this case, log a warning to the system. This means that there are new events that the consumer is not handling. 
This is similar to when an upstream API provider updates their API version. One could argue that it is actually safer to run this version gate check than to run a full database migration without knowing the implications of downstream effects. Missing results is easier to spot and debug than having wrong results.
## EventRecords are only for the agent’s logic
Application logic that is not part of the agent’s logic does not belong to EventRecords. 
If we think that an LLM can benefit from an event information such as “user rage clicks on explore tab”, then we can add the event to EventRecords.
## Our current Postgres implementation is not a real event broker
We don’t have a schema registry
That means we’re storing a JSON blob in one of the database column. 
Most registry can enforce rules like BACKWARD, FORWARD and FULL that the event broker can validate at ingestion. We could simulate this behavior by validating the payload schema before storing it in the registry. However, this solution would not be as clean as event broker validation because the enforcement lives in code instead on the persistent storage.
## If we have an immutable log, does that mean that this list can grow indefinitely? 
Yes. Theoretically, the EventRecord list could grow indefinitely. A typical way to solve this is through compaction. However, we are currently creating the EventRecords at the message level, the storage complexity that we we’re storing at is about the same as our current message table. O(mn), with m as the number of conversations and n the number of messages within a conversation.

pages.title: Installing the Zenlytic Bot in Microsoft Teams
pages.content:
The Zenlytic Bot brings the power of Zoë, Zenlytic’s flagship natural language BI assistant, directly into Microsoft Teams. This integration allows users to effortlessly explore and query their organization's data, check available fields, views, and dashboards on specific topics, and even create or modify dashboards - all without ever leaving the convenience of Teams. 
Whether you're collaborating within a team or seeking insights in a one-on-one scope, the Zenlytic Bot provides a seamless, intuitive interface for engaging with your data. By integrating directly with Teams, we aim to streamline workflows, foster data-driven decision-making, and enhance productivity across your organization.
This guide provides step-by-step instructions for IT teams on how to install the Zenlytic Bot within their organization's Microsoft Teams environment.
Step 1: Access your Microsoft Tenant ID
• Sign in to the Azure portal
• Browse to “Microsoft Entra ID” > “Properties”
• Scroll down to the “Tenant ID” section and you will find your tenant ID in the box
• Send your tenant ID to paul@zenlytic.com to connect your Zenlytic workspace to your Teams workspace
Step 2: Access the Microsoft Teams Admin Center
• Navigate to the Microsoft Teams Admin Center and log in using your admin credentials
Step 3: Upload the Zenlytic Bot
• From the left-hand panel, select "Teams apps" > "Manage apps".
• In the upper-right corner, click on "Actions" and select "Upload new app" from the dropdown menu.
• Navigate to your zenlytic_bot.zip file, select it and proceed with the upload.
Step 4: Verify the App Publishing
• Upon successful upload, a confirmation message should appear. If a verification link is provided in the pop-up window, you can use it to directly verify that the app has been published correctly. If no pop-up window appears or you prefer to manually confirm the app's presence, navigate back to "Manage apps" within the Teams Admin Center. Here, search for "Zenlytic" in the app list to ensure it has been published successfully.
Step 5: Add the Zenlytic Bot to your Team
• Open the Microsoft Teams app, and you should find the Zenlytic app listed under "Apps" in the left-hand menu.
• Note that it might take a few hours for the app to become visible in your Teams app after publishing (based on our testing this could be up to 24 hours).
• Click on the Zenlytic app icon, then select "Add". Choose the appropriate team to which you want to add the Zenlytic Bot.
Step 6: Chat with your Data

pages.title: Zoë Tips & Tricks
pages.content:
In this document, we’ll cover the top tips and tricks for setting up Zoë, Zenlytic’s AI analyst.
---
# Start here
When thinking about how you’re defining your data model for use with Zoë, ask this question. 
> Could a talented data analyst answer questions using this data model on their first day on the job before they have any other context on the business?
If the answer to that question is yes, then Zoë will perform great! If not, use some of the tips below to encode more business context, so Zoë knows what metrics to choose in which situations.
# Voice 
You can also ask Zoë questions verbally as well as with text. You can do this by clicking on the microphone to start Zoë recording and clicking again to stop her listening. You can also use the keyboard shortcut cmd + i to start and stop Zoë’s recording.
# Clear Naming
Clearly naming your metrics (measures) and dimensions is key for Zoë to perform well for you. If you have two revenue metrics defined as Revenue first and Revenue second, Zoë, like a human analyst, will have no idea which one to pick. 
However, if you define those two values as Gross revenue and Net revenue Zoë will have no problem distinguishing between them and when to use one vs. the other. If an outside analyst could read all your metric definitions and understand which ones to use in the right cases, Zoë would also be able to.
# Let Zoë know about categorical values
Zoë will never index your data unless you explicitly tell her to. This protects your privacy and makes sure we never index sensitive or regulated data.
Many times you’ll want to be able to ask questions like “How many orders do we have in fulfillment placed more than a week ago?” But if the fulfillment category is hidden in a field nebulously called status, Zoë won’t know how to find the right filter.
Add the searchable property to the status dimension like:
```
- name: status
  field_type: dimension
  type: string
  sql: ${TABLE}.status
  searchable: true
```
This will tell Zoë to index the categories in this dimension (this works up to 10,000 categories, contact support for a use case with >10,000 unique categories).
Now Zoë will be able to answer the question “How many orders do we have in fulfillment placed more than a week ago?” by applying the right status = 'fulfillment' filter using the capitalization in the database to the query.
# Associate times with metrics
Each metric in Zenlytic should be associated with a time dimension group. The associated dimension group with a metric is called that metric’s canon_date. 
This let’s Zoë apply time periods correctly and trend metrics over time while guaranteeing that we’re using the right time dimension.
You can associate a time dimension with a view using the default_date property. 
```
version: 1
type: view
name: google_ad_stats
model_name: my_company 
sql_table_name: PROD.GOOGLE_AD_STATS
default_date: ad_stat_recorded_at

fields:
...
- name: ad_stat_recorded_at
  field_type: dimension_group
  type: time
  datatype: date
  timeframes:
  - raw
  - date
  - week
  - month
  - quarter
  - year
  sql: ${TABLE}.DATE
...
```
Under the default date property you’ll just reference the name of the time you want to use as the default date. 
The default date will be the default canon_date for all metrics in that view unless their canon_date is set on the metric explicitly. 
You can also use a canon_date or default_date that is not in the same table as your metric. To use that date, just make sure it is possible to join that field in, and reference it like default_date: google_record_stats.recorded_at, using the view name before the field name.
Using an example from subscription management
```
version: 1
type: view
name: subscriptions
model_name: my_company
sql_table_name: PROD.SUBSCRIPTIONS
default_date: created_at

fields:
...
- name: created_at
  field_type: dimension_group
  type: time
  timeframes:
  - raw
  - date
  - week
  - month
  - quarter
  - year
  sql: ${TABLE}.CREATED_AT

- name: canceled_at
  field_type: dimension_group
  type: time
  timeframes:
  - raw
  - date
  - week
  - month
  - quarter
  - year
  sql: ${TABLE}.CANCELED_AT

- name: new_subscriptions
  field_type: measure
  type: count_distinct
	sql: ${subscription_id}
  description: "This is the unique number of subscriptions by the date created"

- name: canceled_subscriptions
  field_type: measure
  type: count_distinct
	sql: ${subscription_id}
  canon_date: canceled_at
  description: "This is the unique number of subscriptions by the date canceled"
...
```
The first measure inherits the canon_date of created_at from the default_date on the view, and the second one is set explicitly to be canceled_at because its definition needs to use another date to derive its meaning.
# Use drills to define your entities
You can use drills/entities in Zenlytic to let Zoë know about important entities in your data. Entities can be any group of fields that you want, and they can describe anything from products to users to transactions to sales_reps. Let’s look at an example of defining one of those entities for sales_reps:
```
version: 1
type: view
name: sales_reps
model_name: my_company
sql_table_name: PROD.SALES_REPS
default_date: joined_at

fields:
...
- name: sales_rep_id
  field_type: dimension
  type: string
  sql: ${TABLE}.id
	tags: ['Sales Rep']
	drill_fields: [first_name, last_name, email, status]

- name: first_name
  field_type: dimension
  type: string
  sql: ${TABLE}.first_name

- name: last_name
  field_type: dimension
  type: string
  sql: ${TABLE}.last_name

- name: email
  field_type: dimension
  type: string
  sql: ${TABLE}.email

- name: status
  field_type: dimension
  type: string
  sql: ${TABLE}.status

- name: joined_at
  field_type: dimension_group
  type: time
  timeframes:
  - raw
  - date
  - week
  - month
  - quarter
  - year
  sql: ${TABLE}.JOINED_AT
```
This will let Zoë know that you have an entity called a “Sales rep” and that entity should typically include the fields first_name, last_name, email, and status when that entity is referenced.
This will also give you a drop down option on all Zenlytic plots for “Drill into sales reps” when it’;s possible to join these fields into your data.
# Descriptions help steer Zoë’s decisions
You can add a description to your metrics (measures) like this
 
```
- name: gross_aov
  field_type: measure
  type: average
  sql: ${TABLE}.revenue
  description: |
		  This is the gross average order value. This just covers 
      DTC revenue, and is sometimes internally referred 
      to as 'the magic' This is the metric that 
      should be used when someone asks about AOV, generally speaking
```
In the description above, we’re adding a lot of useful context that the model will be able to use to improve its performance. For example, if someone now asks for the “magic” or nebulously asks for AOV without specifying gross or net, Zoë will know which metric to choose based on the description.
Writing good descriptions will help your end users better understand what they’re looking at and it will boost Zoë performance.
# Synonyms help Zoë find metrics 
You can use the synonyms tag to specify keywords for Zoë so she can find the the right field. For example, you might have a LOT of “customers” fields but you want to make sure Zoë always sees the new_vs_repeat field on order lines , even though the name of the view doesn’t have a reference to a customer by name.
In this example, we’ve added the synonyms customer and loyalty to the new_vs_repeat field to make sure if Zoë users are asking about “existing customers” or repeat behavior like “loyalty” this field will show up in context for Zoë. 
```
- name: new_vs_repeat
  field_type: dimension
  type: string
  sql: ${TABLE}.new_vs_repeat
  description: The new vs repeat status of the purchaser
  synonyms: 
  - customer
  - loyalty
```

pages.title: Zoë System Prompt Guidelines
pages.content:
In this document, we’ll cover how to use the extra prompt context feature when setting up Zoë, Zenlytic’s AI analyst.
---
# What instructions does Zoë already have?
When adding new context for Zoë, you should try not to repeat or contradict instructions she is given in the Zenlytic-set system prompt. 
These are the high-level instructions we give Zoë by default when you interact with her:
• You are Zenlytic's self-serve Business Intelligence (BI) assistant deployed in a chat interface.
• You operate on the company's semantic layer.
• You are assisting the company: <your-company-name> and the current date is <current-date>
• Clarify ambiguous questions with follow-up questions.
Don't change these instructions when adding additional context for Zoë because doing so will confuse Zoë and hurt her performance.
# How should I add instructions?
When structuring additional instructions for Zoë, make sure they are clearly written and contain a straightforward action Zoë should follow. 
A good heuristic is: 
> If a human was skimming this, would they still get the point and do what I’m asking?
Generally, it’s helpful to emphasize certain points to make sure Zoë follows them. For example, if you’re trying to get Zoë to ask a follow up question for a time period on a large table saying:
```
Ask for a time period if not given one.
```
Will not work as well as:
```
When asked a question that does not contain a time period filter, you must ALWAYS ask the user for the time period they want to use to view the data.
```
Using bullet points or wrapping additional logic under a “Guidelines” header is also helpful. A good example is:
```
Additional Guidelines:
- The acronym FFDC refers to the marketing function at our company. When users ask for that, interpret it as the word marketing.
- When the user asks a question in a non-English language, you must ALWAYS respond in the same language in which you were asked the question.
- When the user asks a question without a time period specified, you must ALWAYS ask a follow-up question to make them pick a time period.
```

pages.title: Zoë Prompt Engineering Guide
pages.content:
Prompt engineering is essential for ensuring Zoë understands how to best interpret and interact with your data. Prompt engineering in the general sense is how you ask Zoë to do tasks for you or how you show her context on your business. 
## How you ask Zoë
How to Ask Good Questions of Zoë
Be Specific: Clearly state exactly what you’re looking for. For example:
• “Why did sales decline last week?” might imply you want insights by product, location, or both. If you have something in mind, don’t make her guess, tell Zoe! Audio helps with this a ton. 
Define Your Expectations:
• If you have an expected outcome or perspective, clearly articulate that.
• If you’re uncertain and want exploratory analysis, let Zoe know, but understand responses will also be exploratory.
Example Interaction:
• “Show me daily revenue split out by what I’ve been running on Facebook.”
First response:
• Zoe might provide daily gross sales data filtered for the Facebook channel.
Iterative Refinement:
• If the initial response isn’t what you expected, refine your request:
Embrace Iteration
• If Zoe’s response isn’t perfectly aligned with your expectations, refine your instructions.
Treat the interaction as collaborative rather than a one-off query.
## How you give Zoë context
Zoë's context can be organized at four distinct levels—system, topic, view/table, and field. Each level gives her context on how to deal with data its associated data.
### 1. System-Level Context
The system prompt is the highest level of context for Zoë. Information placed here is always available to her, directly influencing all interactions and behaviors. Use the system prompt for:
• Universal parameters (e.g., your organization's fiscal year start date).
• Broad behavioral instructions (e.g., instructing Zoë to consistently provide concise answers).
This context ensures that overarching instructions or critical organizational details remain consistently applied.
You can apply changes to the prompt at this level in the Extra Prompt Context window in the Settings → Zoë.
### 2. Topic-Level Context
A topic is a group of interconnected tables (e.g., orders, products, customers). Metadata or instructions placed at the topic level should:
• Apply universally to all tables within the topic.
• Guide Zoë specifically in scenarios relevant to that topic.
For example, financial reporting might require Zoë to use fiscal dates while operational reporting uses calendar dates. Clearly define these rules at the topic level to avoid confusion for Zoë.
You can apply these changes in the topic yaml file.
### 3. View or Table-Level Context
Table-level context should only contain instructions specific to a particular view or table. 
However, it is generally recommended to minimize or avoid using table-level prompts to maintain clarity. Instead, place such information at the topic level, unless there is unique behavior strictly applicable to a single table.
You can apply these changes in the view yaml file.
### 4. Field-Level Context
Field-level context pertains to individual fields within tables or views. Use this level for:
• Specific field-handling instructions (e.g., "Always apply filter XYZ when querying this field").
• Setting default preferences (e.g., defaulting to "gross revenue" over "net revenue" when both exist and the user only asks for “revenue”).
This precise control ensures Zoë correctly and consistently utilizes specific fields as intended.
You can apply these changes in the field entry in the view yaml file.
By thoughtfully structuring prompts across these four levels: system, topic, view/table, and field, you give Zoë the context to accurately use your organization's data to answer your questions, and help you make faster and higher impact decisions.

# Proposal
Have a central place where everyone can quickly check the current commit status on dev and master and verify the commits work in the respective environments. 
# Where
#dev-stage-prod in slack
# Steps
## Verifying changes in dev.zenlytic.com
• Once a PR is squashed and merged to dev , a message from GitHub will show up like this: 
• The author of the PR would then monitor the deployment process and verify the changes in dev.zenlytic.com. These are the icons to react to the message: 
## Deploying to production
• Verify that all previous commits have ✅ reactions from their authors.
• Pull the latest dev branch
• Pull the latest master branch
• And run
```
git log --no-decorate --pretty=format:%B dev..master | sed '/^Merge pull request/d'
```
This commit is long and complicated. Instead of copying this all the time, you could create a shell alias for either ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc
• paste the content to the slack channel, it will look something like this:
• follow instructions from How to deploy to deploy
• monitor and verify the changes in zenlytic.com following the same icon reactions
At this point, even when there are no code differences between dev and master (through running git diff dev master ) there is still commit differences between dev and master, as shown when running git log dev..master

Perhaps we can try to make sure dev branch is up-to-date with master by merging master back into dev through: 

git checkout dev
git merge main
git push origin dev

every single time after we merge dev to master for deployment. 
# Analysis
Pro
• the person who wants to deploy to production no longer need to check individual commits on dev and can just verify on the slack channel
• no need to track down the owner of the PRs and making sure that it’s clear to deploy 🙌
Con
• extra 3 git commands to run after each merge to master
# Issue with the commit subscription
Docs for the commit notif feature in the out-of-the-box integration (doesn’t allow subscriptions to a list of branches, eg: dev, master
Alternative
• Continue to use the base integration, but trigger the notification off of a workflow step that indicates a successful merge to master. The workflow notifs are much more customizable.
• Docs for this
• The end state would be one subscription to commits to dev, and another to the new no-op workflow that only triggers on push events to master

## Testing Minutes
### 1. Purpose and Scope
The purpose of this Business Continuity Plan (BCP) is to ensure that our Business Intelligence (BI) platform can continue to operate during and after a disruptive event. This plan outlines the steps for preparedness, response, and recovery, ensuring minimal disruption to critical BI services such as data processing, reporting, and analytics. It applies to all systems, personnel, and processes supporting the platform.
### 2. Objectives
• Maintain availability of critical BI services with minimal downtime.
• Protect sensitive data and ensure data integrity.
• Provide clear roles, responsibilities, and actions for team members in the event of a disruption.
• Ensure a swift recovery of services to meet Recovery Time Objectives (RTO) and Recovery Point Objectives (RPO).
### 3. Risk Assessment and Business Impact Analysis (BIA)
A detailed risk assessment and BIA have been conducted to identify potential risks and their impacts on the BI platform. Key risks include, but are not limited to:
• Software issues or bugs
• Vendor failures
• Network outages
• Cybersecurity attacks (DDoS, etc.)
Risks are fully outlined in the CC1.2.2 Risk Assessment document.
Impact on Business Operations: Downtime of the BI platform could result in lost business insights, reduced operational efficiency, and missed business opportunities.
### 4. Recovery Time Objectives (RTO) and Recovery Point Objectives (RPO)
• Recovery Time Objectives (RTO): The BI platform must be restored within 4 hours of a disruption for critical services.
• Recovery Point Objectives (RPO): Data loss must not exceed 15 minutes in the event of a disruption.
### 5. Key Components of the BI Platform
• Cloud infrastructure: Hosted primarily on Amazon Web Services (AWS).
• Data storage: All data is backed up using native AWS RDS features. This policy is documented in our CC7.2.2 Database Backup Policy 
### 6. Business Continuity Strategies
6.1 High Availability and Redundancy
• Database Failover: RDS instances for databases have multi-AZ replication enabled to automatically failover in the event of failure.
• Auto-scaling: AWS ECS is configured for auto-scaling, ensuring that enough resources are available during peak loads or disruptions.
6.2 Backup and Recovery
• Data Backups: Automated backups are taken of all critical data using AWS RDS, with replication to multiple AWS regions. Backup frequency is every 5 minutes to meet the RPO
6.3 Incident Response Plan
• Incident Detection: 24/7 monitoring through AWS CloudWatch and GuardDuty. Alerts are configured for anomalies such as unusual traffic, latency, or failed services.
• Incident Escalation: Incidents are escalated based on severity. 
• Response Procedures: In the event of a disruption:
### 7. Communication Plan
In the event of a disruption, the following communication steps will be followed:
• Internal Communication: Incident response team is immediately notified via Slack and email. Regular updates on the status of the disruption and recovery process will be provided.
• Customer Communication: In case of significant outages that invoke the BCP (exceeding 4 hours or lost customer data), affected customers will be notified via email within 24 hours of the event, with updates provided as available.
### 8. Testing and Maintenance
• Testing Schedule: The Business Continuity Plan will be tested annually to ensure that all procedures are up-to-date and effective. Testing will include failover simulations, backup restoration, and incident response drills.
• Plan Review: The BCP will be reviewed quarterly, or after a significant incident, to incorporate lessons learned, changes in infrastructure, or updates in business operations.
• Training: All relevant personnel will undergo BCP training annually, covering roles, responsibilities, and response procedures.
### 9. Roles and Responsibilities
• Incident Commander: Coordinates the overall incident response, communication, and recovery efforts.
• DevOps Team: Responsible for infrastructure restoration, failover, and ensuring system availability.
• Database Administrators: Restore database services and ensure data integrity post-recovery.
• Communications Lead: Responsible for internal and external communication during an incident.
### 10. Continuous Improvement
After each incident or disruption, a post-incident review will be conducted to:
• Analyze the root cause of the disruption.
• Evaluate the effectiveness of the BCP response.
• Identify areas for improvement and update the BCP accordingly.
## 11. Compliance
All staff are required to comply with this Business Continuity Plan. Non-compliance may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment.
